definitions.definition: used to introduce a word or phrase that contrasts with what was said before

examples.text: I got it wrong. It wasn't the red one but the blue one.
His mother won't be there, but his father might.
It isn't that he lied exactly, but he does tend to exaggerate.
I'd asked everybody but only two people came.
By the end of the day we were tired but happy.

definitions.definition: used when you are saying sorry about something

examples.text: I'm sorry but I can't stay any longer.

definitions.definition: used to introduce a statement that shows that you are surprised or annoyed, or that you disagree

examples.text: ‘Here's the money I owe you.’ ‘But that's not right—it was only £10.’
I had no choice but to sign the contract.

definitions.definition: used before repeating a word in order to emphasize it

examples.text: Nothing, but nothing would make him change his mind.

definitions.definition: used to emphasize that something is always true

examples.text: She never passed her old home but she thought of the happy years she had spent there *(= she always thought of them)*.
He would have played but for a knee injury.
The square was empty but for a couple of cabs.
He might agree. But then again he might have a completely different opinion.

definitions.definition: used before a statement that explains or gives a reason for what has just been said

examples.text: She speaks very good Italian. But then she did live in Rome for a year *(= so it's not surprising)*.

definitions.definition: used to show that everything else is impossible except the thing that you are saying

examples.text: What could he do but forgive her? *(= that was the only thing possible)*

wordOrigin: Old English be-ūtan, būtan, būta ‘outside, without, except’ (see by, out).
